title: George Shultz, Secretary of State Under Reagan, Dies at 100
summary: Republican-establishment figure guided U.S. diplomacy to help bring about end of the Cold War. George Shultz, a pillar of the Republican foreign-policy establishment whose diplomacy helped seal the end of the Cold War, has died, according to a family statement. He was 100 years old.

title: Indian Glacier in Himalayan Valley Crumbles, Causing Flash Flooding
summary: More than 150 people are missing, and at least 14 killed, after surge of water triggers avalanches and knocks over buildings. At least 14 people were killed and more than 150 people missing after a flash flood swept through a Himalayan mountain valley in northern India, slamming into hydropower projects and sweeping away workers at the sites.

title: Elliott Management Explores Raising a SPAC
summary: The hedge fund is looking to raise more than $1 billion for the vehicle. Elliott Management Corp., the hedge fund best known for its high-profile shareholder-activist campaigns, is looking to join the sizzling SPAC craze.

title: Everybody Wants Muni Paper
summary: If you enjoyed Detroit debt, you'll love Chicago schools bonds.. Yield-hungry investors have been piling into riskier assets, and not only speculative stocks like GameStop . For an example of how negative real interest rates are distorting prices, behold the municipal bond market.

title: Chicago, San Francisco Reach Tentative Deals With Teachers Unions on Reopening Schools
summary: Chicago union says members still have to approve plan; San Francisco Board of Education expected to vote on the deal Feb. 16. School leaders in Chicago and San Francisco on Sunday announced tentative agreements with teachers unions to reopen schools, tamping down what had become heated negotiations in both cities.

title: Biden Goes Party Line on $1.9 Trillion
summary: Democrats define bipartisanship as Pelosi agreeing with Schumer.. When George W. Bush took office in 2001 with a Senate divided 50-50, he negotiated his first tax cut with Democrats that passed with 58 votes, including 11 Democrats. Democrats won tax-rebate checks and a delay in the tax-rate cuts for their efforts. This made the bill worse as economic policy, but Mr. Bush made the concessions rather than jam his bill through with only GOP votes.

title: The Supreme Court Steps Up Again
summary: The Justices partially enjoin California's limits on religious services.. Politicians are increasingly trying to restrict core American liberties, and the courts are a last line of defense. The Supreme Court stepped into that breach again late Friday with a partial injunction against California's disparate treatment of religious gatherings in the pandemic.

title: Tightening Oil Supplies Inject New Momentum Into Price Rally
summary: Signs of strength under the surface of the energy market suggest further gains for crude prices, some investors and analysts say. A booming rally in oil markets has pushed crude prices to their highest levels since near the start of the coronavirus pandemic, powered by production curbs and recovering demand.

title: What Time Does the Super Bowl Start?
summary: The Super Bowl starts at the same time as every year: 6:30 p.m.. This year's Super Bowl on Feb. 7 (that's today) between the Kansas City Chiefs and Tampa Bay Buccaneers, will begin at 6:30 p.m. ET. That shouldn't come as a surprise. That's the same time as last year and every year for the last decade.

title: George Pratt Shultz
summary: As Secretary of State, he helped Reagan end the Cold War by winning it.. President Harry Truman's Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, called his memoir "Present at the Creation," an account of rebuilding the postwar world and the realities of a Cold War with the Soviet Union. Former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who died Saturday at age 100, titled his memoir "Turmoil and Triumph," an apt description of the historic role Shultz played in ending the Cold War some 40 years later.

title: We Don't Need Another Patriot Act
summary: New law-enforcement powers would inevitably be turned against minorities and progressive dissenters.. A violent mob stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, intent on overturning the results of the presidential election. We can and must prosecute the people responsible to the fullest extent of the law. But we shouldn't grant those who failed to abrogate liberal democracy a partial victory by rushing to pass unnecessary "domestic antiterrorism" laws that would undermine civil liberties.

title: The Wisdom of George Shultz, 1920-2021
summary: Excerpts of the former secretary of state's contributions to the Journal editorial pages.. George P. Shultz, who served as secretary of labor, Treasury and state, died Saturday at 100. A related editorial appears nearby. These are excerpts of his contributions to the Journal editorial pages.

title: What to Do When There's a Covid-19 Vaccine Glut
summary: Supply is ramping up, but many Americans are reluctant to get the shot and need to be persuaded.. The Food and Drug Administration announced new steps last week to help ensure that Covid-19 tests, treatments and vaccines stay ahead of new, potentially more transmissible and virulent, variants, whose emergence makes widespread vaccination even more urgent. The longer it takes to get the virus under control, the harder it may become. And soon, the problem may be a vaccine glut if demand is weaker than expected.

title: Biden's Troubling Latin Agenda
summary: Funding for political activism and abortion won't create jobs in the region.. When developed countries support equality before the law and property rights in poor countries, the left labels them imperialists. But use U.S. taxpayers' resources to promote the termination of unborn life in poor countries, and progressives call it "health" spending. A similar language game is played when international socialists organize political factions under the banner of "democracy" to consolidate power.

title: See America With an RV, Not Twitter
summary: My son and I found kindness alive and well-and offline.. I spent the first tumultuous week of 2021 disconnected from news and social media, driving from Washington state to California. Having not seen my father since the spring, my teenage son and I decided to rent an RV to go visit him safely-and along the way we rediscovered the decency that has gone missing from our national politics.

title: 'Kill Switch' Review: When 51 Votes Aren't Enough
summary: Harry Reid made frequent use of the ﬁlibuster when he led the Senate. A former Reid staffer is shocked that GOP leaders have done the same.. One thing Americans can probably agree on right now is that Americans don't agree on much of anything. The divisions are reflected in a Senate split between 50 Republicans and 50 Democrats. This might seem like a moment for modesty, but one of the new Senate's first debates was whether Democrats should move to end the filibuster and push their agenda through on a simple majority. (Vice President Kamala Harris breaks ties.) The filibuster rule appears to have received a stay of execution: Two Democrats have indicated that they won't lend the votes needed to abolish it.

title: Rollout of AstraZeneca Covid-19 Vaccine Halted in South Africa
summary: Small clinical trial found that it doesn't appear to protect recipients against mild and moderate illness from a fast-spreading new strain of the coronavirus. JOHANNESBURG-South Africa said Sunday it would temporarily halt a planned rollout of AstraZeneca PLC's Covid-19 vaccine after a small clinical trial found that it doesn't appear to protect recipients against mild and moderate illness from a fast-spreading new strain of the coronavirus first detected in the country.

title: What's the Pro Move for Roasting Chicken?
summary: No single trick delivers the crisp skin and juicy meat we covet. An experienced roaster shares her own, holistic approach, and a recipe so simple and reliable you'll want to use it weekly.. I FIELD more questions than you might imagine on the best way to roast a chicken. It comes up all the time among friends who know I used to cook at Zuni Café in San Francisco, legendary for its version.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Inflation, Unemployment and GDP
summary: Data from China expected to tell two different stories. Inflation data from the U.S. and China highlight this week's economic calendar. Capitol Hill also will be closely monitored for the latest on U.S. fiscal policy.

title: Covid-19's Hit to State, Local Revenues Smaller Than Many Feared
summary: But many face higher-than-expected costs from fighting the coronavirus, with widely varying impacts. WASHINGTON-State and local governments in early 2020 expected the pandemic-induced downturn to decimate their budgets, as millions of business closures and layoffs wiped out tax revenue.

title: Biden Won't Lift Sanctions to Bring Tehran Back to Negotiating Table
summary: Iran must stop enriching uranium before sanctions will be lifted, president says in CBS News interview. WILMINGTON, Del.-President Biden said the U.S. won't make the first move to restart negotiations with Tehran over the 2015 nuclear accord, indicating he would only lift sanctions if Iran stops enriching uranium beyond the limits of the nuclear deal.

title: The Case for Plain Vanilla Gets Its Day in Court
summary: Resume Subscription. The lawsuits started in 2019, when Spencer Sheehan puzzled over a can of A & W Root Beer stamped with the words, "MADE WITH AGED VANILLA."

title: Mediocrity Is Now Mandatory
summary: From stimulus to school admissions, leaders act as if ease is the only worthy goal.. Has an era of American mediocrity begun? In January the College Board announced it would eliminate the essay portion of the SAT, as well as all of the separate SAT subject tests. Their stated purpose was "reducing and simplifying demands on students." Such a burden.

title: The Constitution Doesn't Bar Trump's Impeachment Trial
summary: Removal from office is best understood as akin to a 'mandatory minimum' sentence for a crime.. During the impeachment of Bill Clinton, his defenders argued that his misconduct was ultimately private and didn't rise to the level of an impeachable offense. In the current impeachment of Donald Trump, that's a hard argument to make with a straight face, since the then-president's offenses, culminating in the siege of the Capitol, were obviously public and political. So his defenders claim instead that it's unconstitutional for the Senate to try him now that he's no longer in office.

title: Unity and Vision Elude the Fractured GOP
summary: Rep. Liz Cheney represents her "political brand" rather than her constituents.. In the editorial "House Republican Reckoning" (Feb. 3), you contrast the challenge to Rep. Liz Cheney's leadership position in the House because she took a principled vote to impeach Donald Trump for incitement to insurrection with House Minority Leader Rep. Kevin McCarthy's handling of new House member Marjorie Taylor Greene for championing abhorrent conspiracy theories that embarrass the party and risk becoming its albatross. You could also include among those conspiracy theories the no less bizarre notion that Donald Trump and not Joe Biden won the 2020 presidential election.

title: Long Bonds Won't Help Underfunded Plans
summary: Under current market conditions 50-year Treasuries are no panacea.. In "Need Discount Debt? Try 50-Year Bonds" (op-ed, Jan. 29), Jon Hartley notes that the Treasury Borrowing Advisory Committee advised against issuing these bonds. He writes: "But its analysis missed how many long-term Treasurys could be bought up by defined-benefit pension funds looking for assets that match the duration (interest-rate risk) of their liabilities (payouts to pensioners in the future)." But doing so won't help solve the main problem facing public and multiemployer defined-benefit pensions: underfunding.

title: Biden Puts Democratic Unions Ahead of Children
summary: President Biden is in thrall to the powerful teachers' unions which have adamantly opposed all efforts at reform.. Regarding William McGurn's "Catholic Schools Are Beating Covid" (Main Street, Feb. 2): Jeanne Allen of the Center for Education Reform asks whether President Biden "will support efforts to ensure that poor and working-class kids just like him will have the same life-defining opportunity he had." There is but one assured answer and that is a resounding "no." President Biden is in thrall to the powerful teachers' unions which have adamantly opposed all efforts at reform, including opposition to charter schools, standardized tests and teacher-performance evaluation programs, all of which have proven to be a huge embarrassment to their priorities-union members first, second and third, with kids and parents somewhere below that. He will undoubtedly adhere to the same policies as the Obama administration, which blocked thousands of poor, black students in Louisiana from benefiting from a school-choice program intended to help them.

title: Publishers, Free Speech and Common Business Decisions
summary: The conveniently sudden conversion of progressives to the virtues of hands-off small government and deregulated private enterprise has been fascinating.. Teri Geske's letter "Publishers' Blacklists and Unpopular Speech" (Feb. 1) claiming there are no problems with the suppression of Sen. Josh Hawley's book, because it is a "business decision" and private companies have the freedom to platform who they want, is part of a common refrain from liberals excusing the mass erasure of conservative media over the past month.

title: Connecticut Democrats Push Governor to Raise Taxes
summary: Lamont has argued for holding the line on taxes, plans to introduce budget this week. As Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont crafts a budget plan to close deficits exceeding $1 billion in the next two fiscal years, a coalition of Democratic lawmakers is pressuring him to raise taxes to help residents struggling financially during the pandemic.

title: Reconnect With the Work Friends You Miss
summary: Some people haven't seen the co-workers they care about in person in close to a year-here's how to get your office BFF back in your orbit. For four years, Jennifer Klein and Juline Chutuk saw each other every workday. They shouted back and forth between their offices at the Westlake Village, Calif., mortgage banker where they work, and talked through everything from breakups to glitches they were having with the company's software system. They shared lunch, a Costco membership and a stab at a low-carb diet.

title: Vaccine Promises Fall Short for Many Doctors, Elderly in Europe
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Jamie Raskin Leads Democrats in Trump's Second Impeachment Trial
summary: As lead manager, Maryland congressman seeks to win over GOP senators on incitement charge against former president. WASHINGTON-Rep. Jamie Raskin faces an immediate challenge as the top prosecutor in the second impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump: Many of the senators acting as jurors don't think there should be one.

title: From Amanda Gorman to the Weeknd, a Super Bowl Spectacle
summary: Today's game features blockbuster performers, including The Weeknd, H.E.R., Eric Church and Jazmine Sullivan. And to signify the challenges of the past year, youth poet laureate Amanda Gorman will recite a tribute to everyday heroes.. To broadcast Super Bowl LV in the Covid Age, the NFL had to rethink the game-day playbook. So this year, 30,000 life-size cutouts and a mere 25,000 fans-7,500 of whom are vaccinated health-care workers-will be in the stands at Tampa's Raymond James Stadium (capacity: 65,618) to witness history.

title: China's Economy Isn't Out of the Woods, Despite a Strong 2020
summary: Many see risks if Covid-19 proves hard to contain or consumer confidence doesn't improve. HONG KONG-China weathered the economic fallout from Covid-19 better than any other major country, and economists are predicting a bigger snapback this year.

title: Rough Landing Expected for the Glut of New Small-Rocket Makers
summary: Increased use of compact satellites by companies and military isn't seen supporting the current number of smaller launchers. Companies and entrepreneurs world-wide are working on more than 100 new small-rocket ventures, but industry officials anticipate a shakeout eventually may leave just a handful of survivors.

title: Can You Count On Your Employer to Help You Get the Covid-19 Vaccine?
summary: Employers may offer transportation or other incentives, but getting actual shots to workers remains unlikely-for now. With the Covid-19 vaccine slowly rolling out, many workers are wondering whether they can count on their employer to help them get shots.

title: Inside Repossi's New Monaco Store, Where the Jewelry Seems Extra-Shiny
summary: Designed by Flavin Judd, the store is an example of the jewelry brand's strong connection to the art world. IN 2014, Gaia Repossi, the artistic director of Repossi, tapped architect Rem Koolhaas's firm, OMA, to create the Paris flagship for her family's fine jewelry brand. She was looking for something at the intersection of art, architecture and design, and OMA delivered a glossy store full of reflective metal finishes. Recently, when Repossi turned to revamping the brand's Monaco boutique, she wanted something equally inspired. This time, she chose to work with Flavin Judd, the son of artist Donald Judd and the artistic director of Judd Foundation, on his first retail project. The result, starkly different from the Paris store, offers a subversively spare backdrop for the brand's precious wares.

title: Silver Billionaire Thomas Kaplan Welcomes Trading Frenzy
summary: His investment company, Electrum Group, controls mines that are sitting on about one billion ounces of the precious metal. Billionaire investor Thomas Kaplan had been predicting a rise in silver for years. He just didn't expect it to happen all in one day.

title: Phone Protection Plans: Who Should Buy Them
summary: When it comes to buying phone accident coverage, consider the probabilities, not the consequences. Years ago, my iPhone 7 fell off my nightstand, bounced off a plastic box and landed face down on the hardwood floor.

title: Investors Hit Reset in a Bizarre Market
summary: The average U.S.-stock fund for January was up a minuscule 0.3% after all the dust settled. So, 2021 was supposed to be more normal?

title: A (Ridiculous) Proposal: Tom Brady, in the NFL, at Age 70...On the Raiders
summary: The GOAT loves Florida-and a Super Bowl with Tampa Bay looms. But what about that reliable destination for aging NFL legends?. When is Tom Brady going to be a Raider? Excuse me for asking, but I think it's a fair question. After all, that's what happens to football players when they get old. They retire to do TV, play golf, run for office, complain about the new generation of players, open a bar & grill...or join the Raiders for a final, sunset hurrah.

title: Slow Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout, New Variants Shift Some Business Plans
summary: Some executives see recovery in travel, shopping by spring; others don't expect pickup until later this year or 2022. The slow start of the Covid-19 vaccine rollout, along with the arrival of new virus variants, has dashed some business leaders' hopes for getting back to normal in 2021.

title: As Biden Decides What to Do With Border Wall, Landowners Are in Limbo
summary: President Biden promised to halt construction of the border wall. But landowners fighting eminent domain don't know the status of their land.. MISSION, Texas-The Trump administration's border wall now nearly stretches to the riverside retreat where the Cavazos family fishes, barbecues and earns a living on the Rio Grande. To the west, a recently completed stretch of wall stops at their property line. To the east, the bustle of contractors moving dirt continued this past week around a partially built stretch of wall.

title: Navalny Movement Scraps Protests as It Digs In for Long Haul
summary: Following mass arrests and police violence, the opposition in Russia shifts focus from the streets to the ballot box. MOSCOW-The jailing of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny last month galvanized the biggest popular protests in Russia in nearly a decade, as his supporters were joined across the country by average Russians upset with falling living standards and shrinking political freedoms.

title: How Women Can Ditch the Guilt When Juggling Careers and Family
summary: Resume Subscription. This essay is adapted from Joann S. Lublin's "Power Moms: How Executive Mothers Navigate Work and Life" to be published Feb. 16 by Harper Business, an imprint of HarperCollins Publishers.

title: Clawbacks Are Hard, So Companies Try Postponing Pay Instead
summary: Bristol-Myers Squibb is requiring executives to hold three-quarters of their equity grants for at least a year after they vest. Companies are withholding more of their top officers' pay for longer, hoping to avoid the hassle of recouping money when-or if-executives are later found responsible for misconduct.

title: GameStop Frenzy Is Tough Call for Regulators
summary: Little imperative to act if no market manipulation-and little political will to rein in small investors. Washington was quick to react to the wild ride of GameStop Corp. stock and the social-media-fueled trading frenzy that by some accounts pitted everyday people against Wall Street.

title: Cold Reality Dawns: Covid-19 Is Likely Here to Stay
summary: Ease of transmission, new strains, limits of vaccination programs all mean Covid-19 will be around for years-and a big business. Vaccination drives hold out the promise of curbing Covid-19, but governments and businesses are increasingly accepting what epidemiologists have long warned: The pathogen will circulate for years, or even decades, leaving society to coexist with Covid-19 much as it does with other endemic diseases like flu, measles, and HIV.

title: Tens of Thousands Protest in Myanmar as Fears of Life Under Military Rule Return
summary: Since last week's coup, many activists and civilian leaders have been detained or are in hiding. Loud chants of "We don't want military dictatorship, we want democracy" echoed on the streets of Yangon as tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Myanmar's largest city to oppose last week's coup, putting them on a collision course with authorities, who have violently suppressed such demonstrations in the past.

title: Jeep Super Bowl Ad Enlists Bruce Springsteen to Unite America
summary: Auto brand stands out as most advertisers will mostly avoid mentioning political divisions. Jeep's Super Bowl commercial will star Bruce Springsteen narrating a somber plea to end division in the U.S., in contrast to the lighter tone struck by many of the game's other ads.

title: Chicago Schools Resume Talks Over Plan to Reopen Amid Pandemic
summary: After apparent impasse Friday, mayor says parties now seek 'pathway toward a final, comprehensive deal'. CHICAGO-City leaders said Saturday evening that they had relaunched talks with the teachers union over a plan to reopen elementary schools amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Biden Withdraws From Trump's Pact to Send Asylum Seekers to Central America
summary: The Trump administration said asylum seekers should ask for protection from countries they crossed before reaching the U.S. border. President Biden is ending agreements signed by the Trump administration that allowed the government to send some people seeking asylum in the U.S. to Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador, the State Department said Saturday.

title: Liz Cheney Censured by Wyoming GOP
summary: Third-ranking member of the House's GOP leadership was cited for voting to impeach President Trump. RAWLINS, Wyo.-The Wyoming Republican Party voted overwhelmingly to censure Rep. Liz Cheney (R., Wyo.) for voting to impeach President Trump for his role in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol.
